Terrible definition of what is Socialism and what is Capitalism.

Socialism is not = "more State"

And Capitalism is not = "less State".

Socialism means = more PUBLIC ownership of property (than private), but nobody ever said that it has to be necessarily centralized (could very well be decentralized), even less so in the Government. For example, you can research Participative Economics, Cooperative Enterprises, Consumers Cooperatives, Guild Socialism, and the whole work of guys like Oskar Lange, Paul Cockshott, and Pat Devine.

Also, just like Communism, complete Laissez Faire economies never existed anywhere in the world in history. Because there can't be private property in large scale for a long period of time without some kind of authority to secure it, like Legislative power, Judiciary power, Military, Police, etc, whatever (which kind of explains the transition from Feudalism to Capitalism om history).
In other words, Capitalism doesn't mean just "market economy", but that in that market, the big majority of property is PRIVATE.

1) As a social order, we have to figure out three things:
- What will we produce?
- How to produce it?
- Who will get it?
2) Two different economic systems: market economies and planned economies.
a. In planned economy, government controls labor, land and capital.
b. Communism is primarily defined by the lack of private property. Class-lessness is a symptom of having no private property. There are no communist countries in the world.
c. Often socialism has some private property and some public ownership.
d. Command economy is totally controlled by government.
f. In market economies, individuals control production to get profit.
Invisible hand - the unintended social benefits resulting from individual actions.
"It's not from the benevolence of the butcher, the brewer, or the baker, that we expect our dinner, but from the regard to their own interest."
The mechanism of the invisible hand is that if you produce unwanted or shoddy products, a competitor will produce better more desirable products and put you out of business. This results in businesses that produce the things that people want/demand most, at lower prices.
3) Modern economies are neither completely free market nor planned. There's a spectrum of government involvement.
4) Circular flow model.
a. Modern economy is made above households (individuals like him and you) and businesses.
b. Businesses sell goods and services to households in product market.
c. Households earn the money by selling labor to businesses.
d. Businesses pay for the resources on resource market.
f. Government also buys products and resources, i.e. to buy cars from businesses and hire policemen to drive them.
e. Government gets the money from taxes, households and businesses (and borrowing).

Some notes if anyone needs em!

Economics systems are made when we figure out
What to produce
How to produce it
Who gets it
-2 current day economic systems are market economies and planned economies (which comes down to who owns and controls the factors of production) → Karl Marx classified these as Land, labour, and capital
-Planned economies have government controlling the factors of production
-Karl Marx summarized Communism as the abolition of private property → no country has ever been communist
-Socialist countries have a mix between private and sub-public ownership
-Command economy = everything controlled by the government (including output) , which is opposite to a free market economy (or capitalism) where individuals own the factors of production, and government stays out of production, commerce, and trade → meaning businesses make things with the sole purpose of profit
-Invisible hand of the market = the unintended social benefits resulting from individual actions → why companies that make shitty things go bankrupt
-Government steps in in free markets to regulate production (to ensure proper standards of employment etc) and to maintain rules of law and provide public service like bridges and schools (things that won’t turn a profit)
-Modern economies are a spectrum of planned and free economies with varying levels of government intervention (North Korea ←most countries→ New Zealand)
-Circular flow model:
-Businesses sell goods through the product market to households
-Households pay for goods by selling resources (labour) to business through the resource market
-Government then steps in and helps regulate things by using taxes, and borrowing money
→ gets more complex with international relations, trade, and finance sector
-Your moral compass dictates what you believe is the appropriate level of government intervention, like providing a safety net for those with low incomes, or straying away from those who are in poor situations due to personal choices like drugs or gambling

The Circular Flow Model [5:38] also explains what's going wrong in the American economy:

By raising prices while keeping wages stagnant, wealth accumulates in the hands of businesses while simultaneously creating a precarious environment for households, increasing competition in the resource market. Especially once businesses are able to sell each-other automated systems and further reduce their need for labour.

Eventually, a small subset of business owners accumulate the vast majority of available wealth and use it to influence the government to further tilt market conditions in their favour. This exponentially increases inequality until not enough wealth remains in the system to provide enough demand to support the product market as a whole and the economy collapses.

Unfortunately, even if businesses were legally required to pay more for labour, it only creates an incentive to automate faster and more extensively. Human labour is rapidly being priced out of the market. And without jobs, households have no money to spend, thus destroying the circular flow.

Put another way, you could say that customers are becoming too expensive for businesses.

The economy thrives when it is able to maximize the productivity, both individually and collectively, of its citizens. To this end the government should supply those needs that both quality economic evidence, and stakeholders in society deem are required in order for its citizens to thrive and maximize their productivity (eg education - better educated people tend to benefit the economy more), even going so far as 'saving citizens from themselves' (eg making if more difficult for smokers to smoke, as this would harm both their individual and the public's health, impacting upon the productivity of the economy).

It is for the government to provide a foundation to human thriving. Government can be held to account legally in a way that private industry can not be expected to. Government can also act in in the public interest in a way which, whilst unprofitable for any individual corporation to undertake, is nonetheless beneficial to the wider economy as a whole. Furthermore, most human needs are unanimous, whereas preference is individual, therefore human needs require only be met with a cost effective solution in order to provide a foundation for people to thrive. The hungry and thirsty do not worry excessively over their preference for the taste of food and water so long as it nourishes them.
This foundation having been established, it is for the market and the individuals that constitute it, to, through our manifold human desires and preferences, maximize their economic fruits with all the diversity and creativity that would entail.

TL;DR The economy is optimized when we maximize the individual potential of citizens that make up the economy. There are basic things we all can almost unanimously agree upon that are needed in order to maximize individual economic potential (eg food, health, education). The government is best placed to provide for these needs and can provide for them in a cost effective manner, because human needs are generally not diverse whereas human desires/preferences are. However past the point of providing this foundation for human thriving, the market and individuals that constitute it are best suited to catering for human desires and provide a better system for maximising economic productivity.

Even there, I see possibility for less government and more privatizations (more free market). We have private armies, private law security firms, and private arbitration. I often have disagreements with anarchists that these are adequate substitutes, but I'm far more willing to go in that direction than in the direction of more government control.

I agree that government should provide law enforcement, a justice system, and a military. However, all else is beyond the legitimate role of government. Education, infrastructure, etc. should be left to a free market. Education should be chosen by individuals based on the educational institution's quality and price. Competition between different providers leads to lower prices and higher quality. Government schools are notoriously poor quality and extremely inefficient. Infrastructure is already built by private businesses. The government just acts as a middle-man. We should remove the middle-man and allow infrastructure to be paid for by those who use it. For example, businesses need customers to be able to get to their locations. They can pay for the infrastructure around those physical locations. There are also private roads, tolls, and plenty of other private options to pay for infrastructure. And there should be no regulation of production. Workers are paid what they are worth to the business. If they want more they can ask for a raise, gain experience/education to be worth more, or work elsewhere. If they don't like the working conditions, they can work elsewhere. Regarding environmental issues, government should again not be involved. If a business is harming your person/property, then you may use the justice system to seek legal action against them. You can also boycott a business that behaves in a way you don't like and you can encourage others to do the same. Also, the government shouldn't provide subsidies to anyone. Subsidizing clean energy has lead to a massive waste of billions as these businesses have failed due to no demand. The government shouldn't be stealing from some (through taxes) to give to others (through social welfare). People should be free to succeed or fail on their own without government support. If you do truly need a little extra help to pick yourself up out of poverty, then there are voluntary organizations where you can seek such help. There should be no government safety net. Voluntary assistance from organizations like charities is fine, and far more efficient and effective at reducing poverty The government has spent billions on fighting a war on poverty and poverty has only increased. Get government out of it.

The beauty of a free market is that it takes the inherent sinful nature of man (in this case, greed and selfishness) and uses them for good. Communism fails because it assumes man is inherently good and that a complex economy can be well-managed by a central government. Free market understands that man is inherently wicked and the economy is simply too complex for any sort of efficient central planning. Also, due to a sinful nature, Communism breeds massive corruption. You only need to corrupt the central planner to corrupt the whole system. A free market can still have corruption, but it is contained within a single business or two. That corruption leads to poorer quality and/or higher prices and inevitably leads to the failure of said business. So long as the government doesn't get involved a prop-up failed businesses through subsidies, corruption is contained quite well.

For reference, I have lived in the following countries as a comparison:

China (Shanghai, Guangzhou)
Hong Kong
Canada (Edmonton)
United States (Los Angeles)
United Kingdom (London, Northampton, Exeter)
Italy (Milan)
South Korea (Seoul)
Singapore
Thailand (Bangkok)
France (Paris)

Now let me re-iterate: Not a single country I've listed has been more of a FREE MARKET ECONOMY than China has been. Sure, they have governmental businesses which operate large corporations, such as the tobacco industry, but in general, no place I've lived in has had more people in business for themselves, pushing to make an extra dollar, close an extra sale, or gain a higher margin than China. The environment is absolutely ruined, the air is poison, the ground water is undrinkable, and that's directly a result of the obsession over growth due to the free market economy, and people scrambling after a starvation crisis which killed off 50 million Chinese people (thanks, Mao).

Main outtakes of this lesson
1) As a social order, we have to figure out three things:
- What will we produce?
- How to produce it?
- Who will get it?
2) Two different economic systems: market economies and planned economies.
a. In planned economy, government controls labor, land and capital.
b. Communism is primarily defined by the lack of private property. Class-lessness is a symptom of having no private property. There are no communist countries in the world.
c. Often socialism has some private property and some public ownership.
d. Command economy is totally controlled by government.
f. In market economies, individuals control production to get profit.
Invisible hand - the unintended social benefits resulting from individual actions.
"It's not from the benevolence of the butcher, the brewer, or the baker, that we expect our dinner, but from the regard to their own interest."
The mechanism of the invisible hand is that if you produce unwanted or shoddy products, a competitor will produce better more desirable products and put you out of business. This results in businesses that produce the things that people want/demand most, at lower prices.
3) Modern economies are neither completely free market nor planned. There's a spectrum of government involvement.
4) Circular flow model.
a. Modern economy is made above households (individuals like him and you) and businesses.
b. Businesses sell goods and services to households in product market.
c. Households earn the money by selling labor to businesses.
d. Businesses pay for the resources on resource market.
f. Government also buys products and resources, i.e. to buy cars from businesses and hire policemen to drive them.
e. Government gets the money from taxes, households and businesses (and borrowing).

It's also important to remember about the poverty debate: poor people spend a bigger portion of their income than rich people, so they can actually stimulate the markets better. It's bad for the economy if too much money gets piled on people who have so much that they can't possibly spend it all anyway. That way you just get stagnation. Also poverty causes loss of potential: talented people who struggle in poverty usually can't use their talents and so the whole society loses that talent. Also income inequality has been linked with increased crime. And the lack of social safety net also discourages risk taking which can also cause stagnation if people don't want to try new things. So transferring money to poor people can be helpful to everybody, not just the poor people. And yes, the rich can profit from it too; even if it's not monetarily a good deal for them, it creates a healthier society overall.

Yes, you can argue that it removes incentives to work, but as far as I'm concerned: just come up with a different type of incentive to get people working. It doesn't always have to be just about survival. It can be about status or success or accomplishment or more money.

+RealTalk I think you misunderstand. The idea of tradeoffs is that those companies have decided that what they are currently doing for profit is the best use of their own personal resources to turn a profit. So a pure sense of "the world has this much metal and plastic, and we still produce all this crap anyway" doesn't really matter. A company's resource is capital. Money. Just money. They take money, buy materials and labor, and they sell whatever it is that they sell. The trade off is like... 8 good phones or 10 crappy phones per unit of time, give or take. Then you sell a good phone for 600 dollars, or a crappy for 400, then good phones win out. But then what about buyers? Only so many people will buy good phones, and so many people will buy crap phones. What if, per unit of time used before, you could sell 3 crappy phones, or one good phone, same prices as earlier. Making crappy phones has just become the more lucrative option, but you only need to make as many as you can sell. So you can make your three crappy phones, plus one good one, and maybe a good tablet, all in the time it takes to sell those things, and that will turn the beat profit for your only resource, money. (because as we all know, time is also money)

It's not true that private producers won't provide law & order, roads or education. They do it already: in the US there are about three private security personel per government police; there are private courts especially between businesses (who really need speedy delivery); there are roughly 2,200 private highway bridges across the states; and there are obviously many private schools.

And what a completely thoughtless argument for government schools! "Consumers cannot make good decisions if they are not educated!" This just assumes that the government is necessary for people to become educated.

The economic case against private provision of these services is thin: either that they produce positive externalities or that they are public goods, in either case not enough of it will be produced, compared to what a fully perfect market or a omniscient and benevolent planner would produce. That's the main argument, never, or rarely, do mainstream economists try to make an institutional comparison between the flawed market system with the flawed government system. Which system actually produces the best goods? I'd be surprised if this series would try to actually answer that question.

For those interested of the case of privat provision of these services, check out these books "The Enterprise of Law", "The Voluntary City", "Anarchy and the Law", "Reclaiming Education", "The Machinery of Freedom", and "Private Governance".

In general like with shoes and cars the idea of a "free market" and competition work out fine. However, there are areas where a "free market" really falls short. And one of them is long term investments and research.
For instance, almost all our scientific breakthroughs have come through so called basic research, that's research without a specific product in mind, kind of an "let's see what happens" approach.
This is the most important type of science we do, and it simply will not be done without government funding it. Take the LHC in Cern for instance, billions of dollars invested to find the higs boson, which we were not even sure were there(hence the experiment), and certainly did not have a product in mind at the end of it. And it costs about 19 million Euros per year just to run the thing.
Or what about space exploration? Absolutely no way the private sector would have started anything space related, because we are talking 50-100 years of investments and research before you can even begin to think about making a profit on something.
Virgin Galactic and SpaceX you say? Well, they are only viable companies because of technology researched for them by governments. And even now, after half a century of investments, the few private companies we have in the space industry are still heavily dependent upon government contracts to make a living.

Healthcare and environmentalism are also two areas where it is highly debatable that it is even possible to create a good system with a free markets approach.

Ugh. Free markets and capitalism are not the same thing. Socialism/communism and planned/command economies are not the same thing. They are two orthogonal issues: one is about concentrated control vs distributed control, one is about concentrated reward vs distributed reward.

Socialism and communism, which want to distribute reward, are opposed to capitalism, which concentrates reward in the hands of the capitalist (i.e. the upper classes). Free markets, which want to distribute control, are opposed to planned or command economies, which concentrate control in the hands of some bureaucracy.

In addition to planned socialist economies (which use central control to distribute reward) and free capitalist economies (which allow distributed control but concentrate reward), you can also have planned capitalist economies like the fascism or corporatism of Mussolini or the mercantilism of all of old Europe, where control is concentrated in the hands of the government and reward is concentrated in the hands of those they endorse; and, most to my point, market socialism as promoted by libertarian socialists, distributivists, and the like, where control is distributed and reward is kept from concentrating (i.e. remains distributed) without employing concentrated control.

Eg the USA spends more in taxes per person for healthcare than the UK (with its universal, free at point of use healthcare system) and that cost from taxes gets most US citizens nothing. The rest is made up by private spending in the USA (very little in the UK) to bring the cost from the USA's GDP to double what the UK does and for the same or worse outcomes in most cases. 

So what I would have liked is a more nuanced approach. Some effort to separate out when the 'market' is bad. This is left down to personal preference, and in some cases it will be but there must be some studies able to objectively find sectors where the 'free hand of the market' really fails. It's worth noting that what's really going on here is not a one dimensional spectrum but really a complicated mish-mash of different systems. Just to keep things simple, Denmark for instance is very socialist when it comes to the video's question number 3, who gets the resources with it's extensive transfer payments. However, Denmark is notably much more free market when it comes to who produces goods and how they produce them. China actually is still rather socialist when it comes to production and how production is done (government owned companies are still a very large, though decreasing, sector of the economy), but fairly laissez-faire when it comes to who gets resources (thus China's high and growing inequality).

In addition, there are different ways for governments to control the means of production that lead to different outcomes. Both France and Egypt tend to intervene fairly frequently in how businesses are run. However in France those interventions tend to be less biased in favor of particular companies, more open to international competition, and not focused on ensuring particular individuals take over the company. In Egypt, these regulations tend to be a way for the government to reward cronies and punish dissenters. As such France is still able to maintain a rich first world economy (if less rich than less business-operations-intervening countries like Switzerland, Canada, or the United States) while Egpyt is mired in economic stagnation and poverty.

To the extent that there seems to be consensus among economists in the modern world, most agree that having primarily free market attitudes towards who produces most goods and services is good, heavy debate exists on the extent of how much planing should go into how goods and services are produced though with some tendency to say at least partially free market methods are good, and more debate surrounds the question of how planned versus free market the final distribution good and services is, though most are OK with at least some intervention.

I know that it's a 10 minute video that's just an introduction and as such it's rather good. But I just wanted to add on top of that to show just how complex real world economic systems can be. A nation that nationalizes an industry may not provide universal health care. A country that has no minimum wage can still have a generous basic income and etc. The first step to understanding the world complexly in economics is to understand that just because political groups in a country tend towards supporting a given set of policies does not mean that those policies necessarily must all go together.

Firstly, let me start off by saying that I absolutely LOVE that they pointed out how values are the main predictors of what economic system you will favor (to a point).

There are also a few things that I have a problem with:
1) Denmark is not socialist. They are fundamentally capitalistic with some socialist aspects. Generally, individuals still own the means to production, except for some very specific industries.
2) There's a reason no communist country has every really existed, namely, because communism depends on ideals that don't exist in the real world. It's only possible if everyone agrees on the vast majority of things, and no one has any desire to compete economically.
3) Economically, the government is an inherent drain on the cycle they mentioned. While it's true that taxes take out of one sector, and those taxes are spend on other sectors, it's also true that money and efficiency is always wasted within the bureaucracy. Any time you add a middleman you decrease efficiency. So one must ask themselves if the services provided by the government is worth that decrease in overall economic growth.
